text: Early detection and management of chronic Kidney disease This webinar will start shortly. Early detection and management of chronic Kidney disease Zoom webinar Wednesday 16 October 7. 00 pm to 8. 00 pm Acknowledgement of traditional owners We acknowledge the Tasmanian Aboriginal people as the traditional owners and ongoing custodians of the land on which we are meeting today. We pay our respects to Elders past and present. We would also like to acknowledge Aboriginal people who are joining ultrasound today. Learning outcomes After this session, I will be able to: Outline the importance of early detection for those at risk of chronic Kidney disease Describe the elements of the assessment for chronic Kidney disease (Kidney Health Check) Define the treatment options to delay progression of Kidney disease Some housekeeping Tonights webinar is being recorded Please use the Zoom QA feature to ask questions At the end of the webinar your browser will automatically open an evaluation survey. We appreciate you taking the time to complete this to help ultrasound improve our events programme Please dont forget to register for your next webinar at: Presenter(s) Professor Matthew Jose, Head of Nephrology (Royal Hobart Hospital) Emily Beadle, chronic kidney disease Educator (Royal Hobart Hospital) v0724 7 Early detection and management of Chronic Kidney Disease Primary Care Education Workshop This module was conceived and developed by PEAK Presented by: Professor Matthew Jose, Head of Nephrology (Royal Hobart Hospital Emily Beadle, chronic kidney disease Educator (Royal Hobart Hospital) 7 8 Acknowledgement of Country 9 Recognition Thanks to the Primary Care Education Advisory Committee for Kidney Health Australia (PEAK) who has developed and reviewed this education. Thanks to our volunteer presenters! Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 9 Thanks to our sponsors The Kidney Health Australias workshop program has been supported by Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 10 11 This education has been developed in reference to the Kidney Health Australia Chronic Kidney Disease Management in Primary Care 5th edition handbook. To enhance your learning experience please download the app version chronic kidney disease Go! from your iPhone or Android app store. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 11 12 Why use the chronic kidney disease Management handbook app? Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) management in Primary Care handbook provides best practice recommendations for detecting and managing chronic kidney disease in primary care: Easy to use and interactive. Colour coded chronic kidney disease staging table. Colour coded clinical action plans outlining goals of management, key management tasks and treatments to slow the progression of chronic kidney disease. Medication advice and treatment targets. Management framework for common chronic kidney disease complications. Nephrology referral algorithm. Links to additional resources for you and your patients. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 13 Learning aim Learning outcomes Outline the importance of early Provide the tools to drive detection for those at risk of the early detection of Chronic Kidney Disease Chronic Kidney disease Describe the elements of the (chronic kidney disease) in a primary care assessment for Chronic Kidney Disease (Kidney Health setting, using optimal Check)Check) management of chronic kidney disease to Define the treatment options to slow or halt disease delay progression of Kidney progression. disease Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 13 14 What is chronic kidney disease? chronic kidney disease is defined as Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024.

text: Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 25 Case study - Audrey Past medical history History of overweight /obesity (current body mass index 31kg/m2) Mild intermittent asthma Chronic Low back Pain Mild hypertension Family history Maternal grandmother died of a Heart attack in her 60s but also had a history of Kidney problems Mother has type 2 Diabetes Father has angina and hypertension Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 26 Case study - Audrey 20-25 cigarettes per day Smoker (25 pack-year history) 1-2 glasses of wine Alcohol 3-4 nights per week Allergies Nil known Salbutamol 100mcg/dose Medications as needed Low dose ACE/angiotensin receptor blocker Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 27 Who should be offered a Kidney Health Check? /vaper Audrey fits 2 into 4 of these groups, Audrey has a High risk for Diabetes but currently not diagnosed possibly 5 1. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care, (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia: Melbourne, 2024 2. Recommendations for culturally safe Kidney care for First Nations Australians. 2022 Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 27 28 What are the elements of targeted assessment for chronic kidney disease in at risk groups? (choose multiple options) a) Serum Creatinine and estimated glomerular filtration rate b) Renal imaging c) Blood Hypertension measure d) Urine Protein: Creatinine Ratio (urine protein-to-creatinine ratio) e) Urine dipstick Question f) Urine Albumin: Creatinine Ratio (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio) Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 28 29 What are the elements of targeted assessment for chronic kidney disease in at risk groups? a) Serum Creatinine and estimated glomerular filtration rate b) Kidney Imaging c) Blood Hypertension measure d) Urine Protein: Creatinine ratio (urine protein-to-creatinine ratio) Answer e) Urine dipstick f) Urine Albumin: Creatinine Ratio (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio) Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 29 30 How to detect chronic kidney disease Complete a Kidney Health Check every 1-2 years annually for individuals living with Diabetes or hypertension and First Nations Australians 18 years Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. and over. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 31 Early detection of chronic kidney disease in nonIndigenous Australians Indication for assessment Recommended frequency Assessment Diabetes / Hypertension Annually Complete a Kidney Health Check: Established cardiovascular disease Every 2 years Family history of Kidney 1. Blood Hypertension check failure 2. urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (first morning void Obesity preferably) Smoking/vaping 3. estimated glomerular filtration rate History of acute Kidney Every year for first 3 years injury post acute kidney injury, then every 2 years If results indicate chronic kidney disease, repeat Aged ≥ 60 years Once off, unless developing tests. other indications for assessment Refer to of the handbook Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care, 5th edition. Kidney Health Australia: Melbourne, 2024 Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 32 Early detection of chronic kidney disease in First Nations Australians Indication for Recommended Assessment assessment frequency Aged 18 years As needed. Screen for red flags of chronic kidney disease: Family history of chronic kidney disease Clinical history of Diabetes, hypertension, obesity, smoking, established cardiovascular disease, acute kidney injury, Low birth weight or recurrent childhood infections Complete Kidney Health Check if concerned. Aged ≥ 18 years At least annually. Complete a Kidney Health Check. Utilise MBS item 715, if appropriate.

metadata.source_file: E143 - Chronic Kidney Disease education - Powerpoint.pdf

text: Aged ≥ 18 years At least annually. Complete a Kidney Health Check. Utilise MBS item 715, if appropriate. Refer to of the handbook Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care, 5th edition. Kidney Health Australia: Melbourne, 2024 Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia Initial detection and diagnosis of chronic kidney disease Offer a Kidney Health Check to people with Diabetes Hypertension Established cardiovascular disease Family history of Kidney failure Obesity (body mass index 30) Current or former smoker or vaper History of acute kidney injury First Nations Australians aged 18 years All Australians aged 60 years Refer to algorithm on of the handbook Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 33 Algorithm for initial detection and diagnosis of chronic kidney disease cont Refer to algorithm on of the handbook Enter diagnosis into the practice software as a coded diagnosis Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 34 What is Glomerular estimated glomerular filtration rate (glomerular filtration rate)? Accepted as the best measure of Kidney function. Can be estimated from serum Creatinine using prediction equations. ≥ 50% function lost before serum Creatinine is outside the normal range. Normal serum Creatinine levels do not exclude serious loss of Kidney function. estimated glomerular filtration rate Indicates ≥ 90 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 Normal glomerular filtration rate in healthy adults (declines with age) Preserved Kidney function unless there is evidence of Kidney 60-89 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 damage Consistently chronic kidney disease ≤ 59 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 35 Interpreting estimated glomerular filtration rate results Clinical situations where estimated glomerular filtration rate results may be misleading acute changes in Kidney function People under the age of 18 years people on Dialysis severe Liver disease present exceptional dietary intake drugs interacting with Creatinine (e. g. vegetarian diet, High Protein diet, recent consumption of excretion (e. g. trimethoprim) cooked meat, Creatinine supplements) extremes of body size estimated glomerular filtration rate values above 90mL/min/1. 73m2 diseases of skeletal muscle, pregnancy paraplegia or amputees (may overestimate estimated glomerular filtration rate) or High muscle mass (may underestimate estimated glomerular filtration rate) Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 36 37 How to detect albuminuria An initial urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio test should be repeated on a first void sample if the results are positive for albuminuria as urinary Protein excretion follows a circadian pattern. Where first morning void not possible, random spot specimen for urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is acceptable. Dipsticks for Protein in the Urine are now no longer recommended due to poor sensitivity and specificity. urine protein-to-creatinine ratio tests may miss microalbuminuria, resulting in false-negative results. 24-hour Urine collection is not warranted to quantify proteinuria. urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio criteria for chronic kidney disease is not applicable in pregnancy. Dont let perfection get in the way of testing! Random sampling is better than NOT AT ALL Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024.

metadata.source_file: E143 - Chronic Kidney Disease education - Powerpoint.pdf

text: Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 37 38 Repeating the Urine albumin-creatinine ratio Factors other than chronic kidney disease known to increase Urine albumin excretion: Urinary tract infection High dietary Protein intake Congestive Heart failure Acute febrile illness Heavy exercise within 24 hours Menstruation Genital discharge or infection Drugs e. g. NSAIDS Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 39 Case study Audrey - first examination results You decide that based upon Audreys increased risk of chronic kidney disease, she should have a Kidney health check. Audreys Kidney health check results reveal the following: Audreys Kidney Health Check results Normal results Creatinine 128 µmol/L 115µmol/L estimated glomerular filtration rate 55 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 90 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 Urine albumin-creatinine ratio 15 magnesium/mmol 3. 0 magnesium/mmol 130/80 mmHg Blood Hypertension 155/95 mmHg (target) Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 40 Do Audreys Kidney Health Check results mean she has Chronic Kidney Disease? a) Yes b) No c) Maybe Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 40 41 Do Audreys Kidney Health Check results mean she has Chronic Kidney Disease? c) Maybe Remember To diagnose Audrey with chronic kidney disease, her Urine albumin-creatinine ratio and estimated glomerular filtration rate needs to be repeated twice over 3 months (preferably first morning void). Answer However, as Audreys estimated glomerular filtration rate is 60 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 and urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio 3 magnesium/mmol, retest within 7 days to exclude acute Kidney injury (acute kidney injury). Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 41 42 Hypertension targets Treatment should always be individualised and in some patients, it may be appropriate to aim for a lower blood pressure target Treatment targets should take into account the risk / benefit scenario along with clinical practicalities Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 42 43 Blood Hypertension reduction Reducing Blood Hypertension to below target levels is one of the most important goals of chronic kidney disease management. Lifestyle changes should always be advocated and can have significant effect on blood pressure. ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker is recommended first line therapy. Hypertension may be difficult to control, and multiple (3 or more) medications are frequently required. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 43 44 Audrey should not be started on an Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (angiotensin receptor blocker) to slow progression of Kidney disease as it is too early in the condition. a) True b) False Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 44 45 Audrey should not be started on an Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (angiotensin receptor blocker) to slow progression of Kidney disease as it is too early in the condition.

metadata.source_file: E143 - Chronic Kidney Disease education - Powerpoint.pdf

text: a) True b) False angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker therapy: can be prescribed safely at all stages of chronic kidney disease; has been shown to reduce the risk of CV events and death in people Answer with chronic kidney disease, and maximal tolerated dose of ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker is recommended. combined angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and angiotensin receptor blocker therapy is NOT recommended. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 45 46 renal artery stenosis blockade and Kidney function Clinical tip ACE inhibitors and ARBs cause a reversible reduction in glomerular filtration rate when treatment initiated. Check estimated glomerular filtration rate within 2 weeks following initiation. Provided reduction is 25% within 2 weeks of starting therapy, the ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker should be continued. If reduction is than 25% below the baseline value, discontinue and consider referral to a nephrologist. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 46 47 Case study Audrey returns to see you to review tests for Urine albumin-creatinine ratio, estimated glomerular filtration rate, and you take her Blood Hypertension for the 3rd time. Test 1st visit 2nd visit 3rd visit (7days later) (3 months later) estimated glomerular filtration rate 55 54 52 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 Urine albumin-creatinine ratio 15 30 23 magnesium/mmol magnesium/mmol magnesium/mmol blood pressure 155/95 mmHg 155/95 mmHg 145/80 mmHg Tests were repeated seven days later. Refer to algorithm on Then repeated within three months as the results were stable. of the Audrey was started on a Low dose ACE/angiotensin receptor blocker at the 2nd visit. handbook Refer to the algorithm for the Initial Detection of chronic kidney disease in the Chronic Kidney Disease Management in Primary Care handbook or chronic kidney disease Go! app. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 48 Case study - Audrey You can now record Audreys diagnosis as chronic kidney disease stage 3a with microalbuminuria. You ensure that chronic kidney disease Stage 3a is coded as a diagnosis in her medical record and review the Orange Clinical Action Plan in the chronic kidney disease Go! app (or chronic kidney disease Management in Primary Care handbook). You ask reception to book Audrey in for a GP Management Plan (MBS item 721). chronic kidney disease Stage 3a Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 48 49 Colour-coded action plans Enter review reminders and into practice software Refer to action plans on page Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. 27 of the handbook Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 50 What are the key treatment interventions for Audrey now that you have diagnosed her with chronic kidney disease?

text: (choose multiple options) a) Lifestyle modification b) Blood Hypertension management c) Cardiovascular risk reduction d) Lipid lowering treatment e) Adjust medications to Kidney function Question f) Sick day action plan g) Referral to nephrologist h) Referral to the Kidney Helpline for non-medical advice for people living with chronic kidney disease 1800 454 363 Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 50 51 What are the key treatment interventions for Audrey now that you have diagnosed her with chronic kidney disease? a) Lifestyle modification b) Blood Hypertension management c) Cardiovascular risk reduction d) Lipid lowering treatment e) Adjust medications to Kidney function f) Sick day action plan Answer g) Referral to nephrologist? h) Referral to the Kidney Helpline for non-medical advice for people living with chronic kidney disease 1800 454 363 Refer to the Orange Action Plan in the Chronic Kidney Disease Management in Primary Care handbook (or chronic kidney disease Go! App) for more interventions Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 51 Nutrition and diet lifestyle modification Target Detail Healthy Vegetables, fruit, wholegrains, nuts and legumes, dairy foods, lean dietary meat, poultry, Fish and plant Protein. pattern Associated with reduced risk of mortality, Kidney failure, developing chronic kidney disease, and progression of chronic kidney disease Can reduce rate of Kidney function decline, decrease body weight and Blood Hypertension, and metabolic acidosis. Fluid Make Water the Drink of choice. Refer to No recommended number of glasses to consume daily. action plans Drink to thirst. on of Avoid Glucose sweetened beverages they have shown to elevate the handbook risk of and progression of chronic kidney disease. Salt Reduce intake to 5g per day Ultra- Avoid foods High in fat, Glucose and salt e. g. biscuits, cakes, processed packaged snack foods, takeaway foods, energy drinks, fruit juices foods and cordials. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 52 Alcohol lifestyle modification Australian guidelines recommend healthy men and women should Drink no more than 10 standard drinks a week and no more than 4 standard drinks on any one day to reduce the risk of harm from alcohol-related disease or injury. There are no specific recommendations about safe levels of alcohol consumption people with chronic kidney disease, however the less you Drink, the lower your risk of harm from alcohol. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 53 54 What about Audreys cardiovascular disease risk? Should it be determined using the Australian cardiovascular disease risk calculator? a) True b) False Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 54 55 What about Audreys cardiovascular disease risk? Should it be determined using the Australian cardiovascular disease risk calculator? a) True b) False Why? Because the presence of albuminuria is an important prognostic Answer feature of chronic kidney disease, and the driver of cardiovascular disease. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 55 56 Cardiovascular risk assessment in chronic kidney disease chronic kidney disease is a potent risk factor - more than Diabetes.

metadata.source_file: E143 - Chronic Kidney Disease education - Powerpoint.pdf

text: Reduced estimated glomerular filtration rate and presence of albuminuria are independent risks for cardiovascular disease. The Australian cardiovascular disease risk calculator can be used to estimate cardiovascular disease risk, but determine chronic kidney disease before using the calculator www. cvdcheck. org. au. People with moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate 45 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2 and/or urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio 30mg/mmol have pre-determined High risk of a cardiovascular disease event in 5 yrs (≥ 10% probability). For people with estimated glomerular filtration rate 45-59mL/min/1. 73m2 and/or 3-30mg/mmol, consider reclassification to a higher risk category. New cardiovascular disease Guidelines were launched July 2023 www. cvdcheck. org. au Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 57 Lipid lowering and glycaemic control Lipids Audreys lipids should be assessed Lipid-lowering treatment should be considered for cardiovascular disease risk reduction Glycaemic control Audreys glycaemic control should be assessed For people with Diabetes, Blood glucose control significantly reduces the risk of developing chronic kidney disease, and in those with chronic kidney disease reduces the rate of progression Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 58 Statin therapy for chronic kidney disease All adults with newly identified chronic kidney disease, fasting lipid profile evaluation is recommended. Follow-up measurement of lipid levels may not be needed. Consider secondary causes and specialist evaluation if LDL-cholesterol 4. 9 millimoles per liter or triglycerides 11. 3 millimoles per liter. Statin (/-ezetimibe) for: Non-Indigenous people with chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate ≥15ml/min/1. 73m2) and cardiovascular disease risk ≥10% First Nations Australians with chronic kidney disease and cardiovascular disease risk ≥5%. Lifestyle advice if hyper-triglyceridaemia is present. Refer to: CARI Guidelines: Management of cholesterol-lowering therapy in people with chronic Kidney disease. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 59 Audrey has not been diagnosed with Diabetes. Would you start her on a SGLT2 inhibitor at this stage? a) Yes b) No c) Maybe Question Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 59 60 Audrey has not been diagnosed with Diabetes. Would you start her on a SGLT2 inhibitor at this stage? a) Yes b) No c) Maybe Answer Audrey does meet the PBS criteria to be prescribed a SGLT2 inhibitor for chronic kidney disease. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 60 61 SGLT2 inhibitors for chronic kidney disease When can I use SGLT2 inhibitors in chronic kidney disease? PBS Criteria Authority Streamline 13220: Diagnosis of proteinuric chronic kidney disease (with or without Diabetes) present for ≥ 3 months prior to prescribing. estimated glomerular filtration rate 25 - 75 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2. urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio 22. 6 - 565 magnesium/mmol. Must be stabilised, for at least 4 weeks, on either: (i) an ACE inhibitor or (ii) an angiotensin II receptor antagonist. Do not use in combination with another SGLT2 inhibitor. Not recommended to initiate if estimated glomerular filtration rate 25 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2. May be prescribed by nurse practitioners (continuing therapy only). Dapagliflozin for chronic Kidney disease: a new indication and clinical criteria have been added to the PBS listing for dapagliflozin. NPS MedicineWise website. New PBS listing: Dapagliflozin for chronic Kidney disease (nps. org. au). Accessed Sep 7, 2022.

metadata.source_file: E143 - Chronic Kidney Disease education - Powerpoint.pdf

text: NPS MedicineWise website. New PBS listing: Dapagliflozin for chronic Kidney disease (nps. org. au). Accessed Sep 7, 2022. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 62 SGLT2 inhibitors Clinical tip SGLT2 inhibitors cause a reversible drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate 4 weeks after initiation, then rebounds. Specific testing of estimated glomerular filtration rate for this purpose is not required. SGLT2 inhibitors cause osmotic diuresis, reduce diuretics and/or antihypertensive medications upon initiation of an SGLT2 inhibitor. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 62 63 SGLT2 inhibitors and estimated glomerular filtration rate EMPA-REG OUTCOME TRIAL J Am Soc Nephrol 28: 10231039, 2017. doi: 10. 1681/American Society of Nephrology. 2016060666. Adapted from Wanner et al. NEJM 2016 Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 63 64 estimated glomerular filtration rate and medication dosing Dose reduction of some drugs is recommended for patients with reduced Kidney function. Both estimated glomerular filtration rate (milliliters per minute/1. 73m2) and estimated creatinine clearance (milliliters per minute) provide an estimate of relative Kidney medication clearance. If using estimated glomerular filtration rate for therapy dosing, body size should be considered, in addition to referring to the approved Product Information. For medications with a narrow therapeutic index, therapeutic medication monitoring or a valid marker of therapy effect should be used to individualise dosing. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 65 Sick day action plan REMEMBER Ensure patients/clients have a sick day action plan to prevent acute Kidney injury. Mnemonic for drugs to be avoided on a sick day (SADMANS) How to guides available in the Kidney Health Professional Hub Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care, 5th edition. Kidney Health Australia: Melbourne, 2024. Not to be reproduced without permission from Kidney Health Australia 66 Nephrology referral guidelines Refer to action pans on of the handbook Where referral to a Nephrologist is not possible, as may be the case for people located in regional and remote areas, we recommend contacting your supporting Kidney service to discuss options for referral, which may include telehealth consultations. Chronic Kidney Disease (chronic kidney disease) Management in Primary Care (5th edition). Kidney Health Australia, Melbourne, 2024.
